title: 110_hr6385
content: Upon enactment of this Act, the Budget Committees of the House and Senate will reduce the budget authority allocation by $14.8 billion for fiscal year 2009. They will also make necessary adjustments to the budget resolution. Additionally, there will be conservation of resources fees implemented. The Secretary of the Interior will establish conservation of resources fees for producing and nonproducing Federal oil and gas leases in the Gulf of Mexico within 60 days of the Act's enactment. The fee for producing leases will be $9 per barrel for oil and $1.25 per million Btu for gas in 2005 dollars. The conservation of resources fees for Federal oil and gas leases in the Gulf of Mexico will vary based on production levels and lease status. For producing leases, the fee will be determined by the average daily closing prices for oil and gas, while nonproducing leases will have a set fee of $3.75 per acre per year. These fees will be applicable starting October 1, 2006. The term "covered lease" in this section refers to oil or gas production leases in the Gulf of Mexico existing before the enactment of the Act, issued by the Department of the Interior under specific regulations, and not subject to certain royalty relief limitations. Amounts received as fees under this subsection will be treated as offsetting receipts. The Secretary of the Interior may amend leases for Gulf of Mexico tracts to include price thresholds for royalty suspension provisions, set at $34.73 per barrel for oil and $4.34 per million Btu for natural gas. SEC. 503 of the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008 amends payment acres for direct and counter-cyclical payments under Department of Agriculture commodity programs, reducing percentages for program crops and peanuts. SEC. 504 reduces the maximum amount of direct, counter-cyclical, and acre payments for program crops and peanuts under Department of Agriculture commodity programs. The amendment lowers the payment limits from $40,000 to $20,000 for program crops and peanuts, and from $65,000 to $32,500 for program crops. SEC. 505 consolidates the military exchange stores system. The Apollo Energy Independence Act of 2008 mandates the consolidation of the military exchange stores system within two years to improve efficiency and customer service. This consolidation includes the Army and Air Force Exchange Service, the Navy Exchange Service Command, and Marine Corps exchanges into a single administrative entity. Operating costs will be covered after the consolidation is completed. "All operating costs of the exchange stores system will be covered by sales revenues or nonappropriated funds." SEC. 506. REVISED PRICING STRUCTURE FOR DEPOT-LEVEL ACTIVITIES OF THE DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE. The Department of Defense's depot-level activities will now charge only for the incremental cost of repairs, excluding charges for components and fixed costs, which will be covered by an annual flat fee to customers. SEC. 507. RESTRICT UNIVERSAL SERVICE FUND SUPPORT TO 2 CONNECTIONS PER HOUSEHOLD. SEC. 507 amends the Communications Act of 1934 to limit universal service support to 2 connections per household, with savings to be remitted to the Treasury of the United States. SEC. 507 of the Communications Act of 1934 limits universal service support to 2 connections per household, with savings to be remitted to the Treasury of the United States. The Commission directs the Administrator not to adjust the amount of support contributed by telecommunications carriers. Definitions include the Administrator as the designated official for federal universal service programs and the Commission as the Federal Communications Commission. SEC. 508 amends the Right to Financial Privacy Act to allow tracing or recovering improper payments by the Secretary of the Treasury. SEC. 509 allows the Secretary to invest Treasury operating cash in repurchase transactions. SEC. 510 pertains to user fees for the Food Safety and Inspection Service. The Secretary of Agriculture will establish and collect user fees for inspection services under the Federal Meat Inspection Act, the Poultry Products Inspection Act, and the Egg Products Inspection Act.
